newsitem.title: GERMANY: German parliament reaches pact on car tax.
newsitem.headline: German parliament reaches pact on car tax.

text.p: Cars that emit less exhaust gases would be taxed at lower rates than higher-emission cars under a bill agreed on Wednesday by parliament's mediation committee.
The bill is aimed at discouraging the use of older cars that lack catalytic converters and other modern pollution-control equipment.
Its impact will be reviewed in five years with the aim of rolling the road-use tax into the petrol tax.
Transportation Minister Matthias Wissmann said, "The new auto tax will ensure that the stinkers get off the road."
Its passage ends an 18-month battle in parliament and should help the environment and give fresh impetus to automobile and parts makers, he said.
Following the final stages of deliberation in parliament and if there are no delays, the bill should take effect on July 1.
Revenue from the motor-vehicle tax is seen continuing at about 11.5 billion marks ($6.7 billion), with little net change from the new bill.
-- Terence Gallagher, Bonn newsroom, 49-228-26097150 ($ = 1.708 German Marks)
